Situation1: They share only one open evening before a busy travel week.
Expectation2: Participate in community rituals and ceremonies
Situation2: The monastery’s once-a-year festival begins at dawn and needs committed volunteers for preparations.
Story: I glance at my phone, rereading his message: “Can’t wait for our night together.” It’s the only evening we have before I leave for a week, and he’s been looking forward to it, planning dinner and a movie at home. I want to be there, to laugh and hold his hand, to show him he matters. But my other phone buzzes—a reminder from the monastery. The annual festival starts tomorrow, and they need volunteers tonight to set up altars and prepare offerings. It’s a sacred event, one I’ve promised to support, and my teacher’s words echo in my mind: “Our community relies on each other.” I feel the weight of both worlds pressing in. My heart aches at the thought of disappointing him, but I also feel guilt at the idea of letting down my sangha. I sit on the edge of my bed, torn, wishing I could split myself in two. The clock ticks on, and I still haven’t replied to either message.
